column4: 1980From United Kingdom Ufologist Jenny RandlesIn November and December 1980
column5: the eastern side of Britain was experiencing a major UFO sighting wave. There were chases of UFOs by police cars near the coast
column6: a UFO that overflew an oil rig in the North Sea
column7: and the wave culminated in the famous events on the East Anglian coast at Rendlesham Forest. Just a month before these landings beside those NATO air bases
column8: one of the most impressive alien abduction cases took place in the small Penninemill town of Todmorden
column10: right in the centre of Britain\'s most active window area known locally as 'UFO Alley'. Police Constable Alan Godfrey was on patrol on the night of 28 November 1980. Just before dawn he drove along Burnley Road on the edge of Todmorden looking for some cows that had been reported missing. They were only found after sun-up
column11: mysteriously relocated in a rain-soaked field without hoofmarks to indicate their passage. Giving up his nocturnal hunt
column12: Godfrey was about to go back to base to sign off duty when he saw a large mass a few hundred yards ahead. At first
column13: he thought it was a bus coming towards him that took workers to their jobs in town and that he knew passed about 5:00 a.m. But as he approached
column14: he realized that it was something very strange. It was a fuzzy oval that rotated at such speed and hovered so low over the otherwise deserted highway that it was causing the bushes by the side to shake. The police officer stopped
column15: propped onto his windscreen a pad that was in the patrol car to make sketches of any road accidents
column16: and drew the UFO. Then there was a burst of light
column17: and the next thing he knew he was driving his car again
column19: with no sign of the UFO. Godfrey turned around and examined the spot where the UFO had hovered. The road was very wet as it had rained heavily earlier in the night. But just at this one location was a circular patch where the roadway had been dried in a swirled pattern. Only when back at the police station did he realise that it was a little later than he had expected - although any missing time was probably no greater than 15 minutes from estimates later taken on site. Concerned as to possible ridicule
column20: Godfrey at first chose not to make an official report
column21: but changed his mind later that day when he discovered he was not alone. After breakfast that morning
column22: a driver who had been on Burnley Road three miles further out at Cliviger reported seeing a brilliant white object and contacted Todmorden police. The time matched that of Alan Godfrey\'s. Furthermore
column23: a police patrol from an adjacent force (Halifax) had been engaged in a stakeout for stolen motorcycles on the moors of the Calder Valley and had witnessed a brilliant blue-white glow descending into the valley towards Todmorden shortly before Godfrey experienced his close encounter. Their story
column24: when it reached Todmorden police station
column25: formed a second match. Encouraged by this news Godfrey filed an official report
column26: but was surprised when police chose to release the story to the local newspaper the following week. From here
column27: UFOlogists discovered the case and a lengthy investigation was mounted by a Manchester-based UFO group.  Although Alan Godfrey had no further conscious recall of the missing time
column28: he did have increasingly confused memory of the sequence of events surrounding the sighting (with an unexplained image of seeing himself outside the car during the sighting). There was also puzzling physical evidence. His police-issue boots were split on the sole
column29: as if he had been dragged along the floor and they had caught on something. He also reported a previous history of seeing other strange things and having experienced at least one earlier time lapse as a youth—factors that UFOlogists have come to recognise as common with abduction cases. When sure that all conscious testimony had been recorded
column30: Godfrey agreed to be hypnotically regressed by a Manchester psychiatrist eight months after the incident. He eventually had several other sessions with different therapists
column31: and his recall in later sessions was video-taped. The doctor refused permission to the UFO group for the first session to be recorded. The hypnotic testimony is very odd
column32: and Godfrey was never to be sure what really happened. Under regression he told of the bright light stopping the car engine
column33: causing his radio and police handset both to be filled with static and then to be swamped by blinding light as he lost consciousness. His next recall was of being inside a strange room
column34: more like a house than a spaceship
column35: complete with a most unexpected large black dog. He was studied by a heavily bearded man who telepathically conveyed that his name was 'Yosef' and whose clothing was very Biblical in nature. Assisting Yosef were several small robot-like creatures 'the size of a five-year-old lad' and with 'a head shaped like a lamp'. They are reminiscent of the 'Grays' of UFO lore; although with major differences. Godfrey was supposedly asked questions
column37: and was promised a later encounter. But apparently he was not subjected to the more familiar indignities of abduction stories (especially from the US)
column38: such as bodily fluid samples and rectal probes. Although there were periods of missing memory
column39: the hypnotic recall that did emerge was a curious hybrid of mythic images
column40: UFO case elements and dream like sequences. When asked his opinion as to the reality status of this hypnotic testimony
column41: Alan Godfrey was refreshingly honest. He told me he was certain that the UFO encounter was real
column42: but he could not determine whether the story offered by hypnosis was a dream
column45: or a mixture of all three. Unhappily
column46: Alan Godfrey suffered terribly after this encounter. When I first wrote up the investigation (just before the regression hypnosis began) for Flying Saucer Review magazine in l981
column47: I deliberately changed his identity to help protect him; although this was probably futile because the story had already been featured in the local press under Godfrey\'s real name. However
column48: despite my refusal to assist them
column49: a tabloid reporter traced the witness and devoted a front-page banner headline article to the story — read by millions over the Sunday lunch—which led to the officer being called to explain himself before his superiors. He was forced to undergo medical investigation to determine his 'status'
column50: but was pronounced psychologically fit and healthy. Yet after some years feeling that he would never be allowed to forget his sighting
column51: he took advice to honorably resign over an unrelated physical injury incurred during an incident in which he bravely intervened to avert a crime. Todmorden
column52: both before 1980 and in the years since
column53: has been a hotbed of alien contact activity with several other major encounters having been investigated
column54: including another abduction of a truck driver from Burnley Road only a little further out of Todmorden and on the same highway. written by... Jenny Randles '
column56: 1980 -  Australian Cattle Rancher Encounters Bizarre UFO In the early morning of September 30
column60: an Australian cattle rancher was awoken by the sound of his frightened cattle. When he went outside
column61: he was astonished to see a domed disc-shaped object with orange and blue lights
column62: gliding about ten feet above the ground. It rose slightly in the air
column65: and then landed fifty feet away.The rancher jumped on his motorbike and sped towards the object
column66: which was making a 'whistling' sound. Suddenly an 'awful scream' sounded as a black tube extended from the UFO\'s base. With an ear-splitting bang
column67: the strange craft rose into the air. A blast of air knocked the rancher down.The sounds ceased as the object slowly moved to a position about 30 feet away and 8 feet above the ground. Hovering briefly
column72: disappearing in the east.A ring of black flattened grass 30 feet in diameter marked the place where the disc had landed. When he examined it in the daylight
column73: the witness discovered that all the yellow flowers within the circle had been removed. Only green grass remained. But one a more bizarre note
column75: with no evidence of spillage. Only the muddy residue at the bottom of the tank was left-and it had been pulled into a two foot high cone shape. The witness was sick with headaches and nausea for more than a week afterward.A similar ring was found the following December at Bundalaguah
column76: not far from Rosedale. The water in a nearby reservoir was also mysteriously missing.source:http://ourworld.compuserve.com:80/homepages/AndyPage/rosedale.htm'
column78: Chapter 2The spectacular events of late 1980 were kept out of the public knowledge for the most part
column79: at least until 1983. An early UFO magazine article about the events brought only a passing interest
column80: yet the story survived on rumor and speculation until Robert Todd of the Citizens Against UFO Secrecy (CAUS) secured a copy of an official report of the events through the Freedom of Information Act in 1983. The paper was dated 1-13-81
column81: and had been sent to the British Ministry of Defense by Halt. The events of Rendlesham have been published in numerous newspapers
column86: ' and the British program 'Strange But True
column89: is similar to the famous Roswell
column90: New Mexico incident in that its investigation involved almost exclusively military personnel. Though the two incidents occurred in totally different countries
column91: both involved United States manned installations
column92: and were close to top secret military bases.  '
